Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Beyond Visualization: A Roadmap To The Next Generation Building Design Environment For Sustainability

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1653054 - (Zhu)

This is a grant in partial support of a two-day workshop focusing on defining a vision and roadmap for the next generation building design environment for sustainability and to foster a community of academic researchers and industry practitioners for realizing the vision. Researchers and practitioners in architectural design, engineering, construction, computer sciences, psychology, physiology and cognitive science will be identified and invited to attend the workshop. Three topics will be covered by the workshop: design for sustainability, human sensations and behavior, and computing and mediation. Keynote presentations, topical presentations, panel discussions and breakout sessions will be organized for the workshop. A project website will be developed and maintained to share the workshop information before and after the workshop.

The questions to be addressed at the workshop include: What can be learned from the evolution of building design environments or tools, from manual drafting, CAD, to now integrated design environments such as building information modeling (BIM)? If CAD is disruptive to manual drafting technologies because of its efficiency and accuracy just like interoperability and integration are the reasons for BIM to be disruptive to CAD, what are the features that the next generation of disruptive building design technologies should have? Answers to these questions will potentially bring about significant changes to future building designs for sustainability. Currently, although elements of technologies have already existed such as immersive virtual environments, lighting simulation, acoustic simulation, energy simulation, and climate control technologies, there are still technical and knowledge gaps that prevent researchers and practitioners from realizing the vision. Therefore, the workshop will provide a unique opportunity for researchers and practitioners to conceptualize a novel framework and develop a practical roadmap for future building design environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Design is a key component for creating a virtuous cycle between existing and future buildings and infrastructure systems. Given the large volume of new and retrofitting projects every year, design plays a significant role in shaping the sustainability of the future built environment. On the other hand, computer-mediated design environments are increasingly applied in design processes; thus, we need to better understand their impact on design for sustainability. In particular, as social, economic, scientific, and technological conditions change, there are new challenges for future buildings to meet and new opportunities for designers to leverage. How such changes will shape the next generation design environment is a key question.

 

A two-day workshop was organized to explore answers to that question. Participants from the fields of architecture, civil engineering, cognitive science, computer science and engineering, construction, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, and psychology participated in the workshop. Keynote and topical presentations, panel discussions, and breakout sessions were organized to explore answers and solutions.

 

The next generation design environment is envisioned as a smart and connected system that is integrated, iterative, human-focused, and collaborative, driven by changes in the socio-techno-economic environment, one that affords new information and computer technologies and new advances in many fields in the sciences. More specifically, the key characteristics of the next generation design environment can be described under four dimensions, or the 4Ps: Performance, People, Product, and Process. Realizing this vision requires scientific underpinning in design, engineering, computing, and social and human sciences, including four general areas:

  1. Experience-focused and evidence-based design;
  2. Context-aware human-machine interfaces;
  3. Decision making environment;
  4. Data and data-driven strategies.

 

The deliverables of this project include this report, a Website and a social network where all project information and documents are stored and shared, and a special collection of peer-reviewed articles on the next generation of disruptive building and infrastructure design and engineering technologies to appear in the Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering published by the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE).

 

Three components – research, applications, and community – must be developed as a next step. It is especially important to create a multidisciplinary community such as a research coordination network to continue discussions about and collaboration on this subject. Future discussions should include topics on the relationships between design environment and new social, economic, and technological phenomena such as smart cities and the food-energy-water nexus, as well as the design environment for other forms of the built environment, such as highways, bridges, and power systems. In addition, industry involvement is key to generating broader impact. Mechanisms for industry-university collaboration that would accelerate discovery and adaption are needed in the future.
